attributes.alt: Cover for Where's My Teddy? by Jez Alborough. Cover shows a scared bear running in a forest, holding a teddy bear.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about the letters
engage children with a movement activity, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
Why does Eddie go into the woods?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Understand and use a growing number of question words (who, what, where, when, why, how).
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?
Are there any bears in the book you are reading? Who is in your book?
Pretend you are Eddie and look for your lost bear.
Show me a counter for the bear, for Freddie and for big Ted. How many counters do you have?
What is the biggest thing you’ve ever seen? Can you write about it and draw a picture?
How can you use the materials to make a giant teddy for the bear?
Draw an O and a P in the sand tray.
How can you build a bed for Eddie and his teddy? Is it the right size?

attributes.alt: Cover for Where's My Teddy? by Jez Alborough. Cover shows a scared bear running in a forest, holding a teddy bear.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about feelings and emotions.
Use information to describe; Use information to compare and contrast.
Write with some letter-sound correspondence writing.
Identify emotions in self; Manage transitions and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Understand and use a growing number of question words (who, what, where, when, why, how).
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Invite children to make a bear puppet.
Encourage children to use the bear puppets to express the bear’s feelings.
How do we measure how big, how much, how many?
How do you feel when you read a book you like?
Can you act out what Eddie does at the end of the story?  How does he feel?
Find two objects. Which one is  big? Which one is small?
Can you make a picture of your favorite stuffed animal and write about it?
Can you make something to make a giant bear happy?
How can you build a bed for the bear and his teddy? Is it the right size?

attributes.alt: Cover for Where's My Teddy? by Jez Alborough. Cover shows a scared bear running in a forest, holding a teddy bear.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with a chant, and introduce vocabulary
How are Eddie and the gigantic bear alike?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Use information to describe; Use information to compare and contrast.
Write with some letter-sound correspondence writing.
Understand and use a growing number of question words (who, what, where, when, why, how).
Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like “small,” “big,” “short,” “tall,” and “long.
Teach children how to measure using Connecting Cubes.
Encourage children to compare and determine how big or how little.
How do we measure how big, how much, how many?
Choose two books. Which is bigger? Which is heavier?
Pretend you are a gigantic bear. How do you feel?
Can you draw trees in the woods? Make one tree big and one tree little.
Can you draw a teddy and label it Freddie?
How can you make your own bear using the things you see here?
How can you build a giant bear using blocks?

attributes.alt:
Big Chart of Big Ideas for I Can Measure. Chart shows a ruler, a scale, a cup, and a thermometer.
Ruler: A hand holds on to a ruler with a short and long pencil next to it.
Scale: A child puts a heavy rock on one side of a scale. A feather is on the other side of the scale.
Cup: A girl pours a little juice into one cup. The cup next to it has a lot of juice in it.
Thermometer: A thermometer has a very low temperature with a snowman behind it. Next to it, finger points to a high temperature on another thermometer showing it is hot.
Cover for Where's My Teddy? by Jez Alborough. Cover shows a scared bear running in a forest, holding a teddy bear.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about ways to measure, engage children with a heavy or light activity, and introduce vocabulary
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question:
How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?
Use information to describe; Use information to compare and contrast.
Write with some letter-sound correspondence writing.
Manage transitions and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Understand and use a growing number of question words (who, what, where, when, why, how).
Use formal or informal measurement tools (e.
g., balance scale, cups, blocks, paper clips, etc.) to observe and describe weight, length, and volume;
Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like “heavy” and “light.
Guide children to explore the concept of heavy versus light using a simple scale (balance or digital).
Ask children to predict before measuring.
How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?
Choose a book. Hold a tissue in one hand and the book in the other. Which is heavier?
Can you put the following items in order, from smallest to largest—plate and cups?
Pick two things. Can you use a balance scale to figure out which thing weighs more?
Can you draw a penguin and a whale, and tell which is lighter?
Can you make three bears in different sizes, and then put them in size order?
How can you put the letter tiles  (from A to P) in ABC order? Sing “The Alphabet Song” to help you!
Can you build a house for the big teddy bear?

attributes.alt: Cover for Where's My Teddy? by Jez Alborough. Cover shows a scared bear running in a forest, holding a teddy bear.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to have children act out a scene from the story and to review the week’s vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
Why wouldn’t you take the giant teddy home?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share and repeat the details in a text.
Write with some letter-sound correspondence writing.
Understand and use a growing number of question words (who, what, where, when, why, how).
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
If you could build your own teddy, how would you make it?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?
Can you pretend to read to your teddy? What story would you choose?
Imagine that you are building a house. Can you pretend to measure the size of the walls, floor, and windows for the house?
Imagine you are the giant bear. How big of a step can you take? Can you work with a friend to measure the step?
Can you draw a picture of Eddie and Freddie?
Can you create a house for Freddie using the materials?
Can you make up a name for the bear’s bear? What letter does it begin with?
Which blocks would you use to make a giant bear?
